Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Unified and Scalable Architecture for Low Speed Automated Shuttle Deployment in a Smart City

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF CPS EAGER project supports the SmartShuttle and SMOOTH II NIST GCTC technical cluster projects of the City of Columbus and the Ohio State University by developing a unified and scalable solution architecture for low speed automated shuttle deployment in a Smart City. This project will help the development of Columbus as a Smart City, having a broad impact on the mobility choices of its inhabitants. The targeted population of this project are the residents of the City of Columbus and more specifically the people who either work in or visit the Easton Town Center outdoor shopping center in Columbus. The proposed use of small electric shuttles as a first-mile, last-mile solution will improve their quality of life as a safe and reliable mobility solution. The results of the proof-of-concept demo will be used to quantify the potential societal impact as the number of people per day who will be able to use the proposed low speed automated shuttle solution in the Easton Town Center area and in other parts of Columbus in a potential future full scale deployment. The benefit to society of this project will be the development of a generic unified and scalable architecture for low speed automated driving shuttles that will be shared with GCTC teams and other interested researchers.

Success of low speed automated shuttles in Smart Cities requires the use of a unified, scalable and replicable software, hardware, control and decision making architecture. This architecture should be easily adoptable and modifiable by different GCTC teams and other users and easily replicable for different deployment sites. This architecture should also be compliant with the automated driving architecture used by automotive OEMs in high speed automated driving. This project has three parts. The first part is the development of a unified software, hardware, control and decision making architecture that uses a model based design approach within the Simulink development environment consisting of generic Simulink interfaces for typical sensors like GPS, camera, lidar, radar and V2V modem, generic Simulink steering, throttle and brake actuators, all within a generic multi-agent Simulink automated driving architecture connected by generic and scalable control and decision making blocks. The second part is the development of a scalable and replicable method of designing longitudinal and lateral vehicle dynamics controllers using the parameter space approach to parametric robust control. The third part is an evaluation and rating system that will be developed to evaluate different automated driving control systems utilizing the unified and scalable architecture of the project. The results will be demonstrated using a proof-of-concept demo deployment in the Easton Town Center outdoor shopping area to solve first-mile and last-mile problems. Scalability and replicability of the proposed architecture will be demonstrated by application to a small two seater electric vehicle and a mid-sized hybrid electric sedan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF CPS EAGER project with acronym UNIFY supported the SmartShuttle and SMOOTH II NIST Global Cities Technical Challenge (GCTC) technical cluster projects of the City of Columbus and the Ohio State University and developed a unified, scalable and replicable solution architecture for low speed automated shuttle deployment in a Smart City. Project UNIFY was in the second wave of NSF’s smart city EAGER projects and started as the City of Columbus won the US DOT Smart City Challenge award. The close cooperation between the UNIFY research team at the Automated Driving Lab of the Ohio State University with the city of Columbus on AV shuttles as first and last mile solutions in the daily commute between home and workplace has been continuing ever since. As a result, the project UNIFY has helped the development of Columbus as a Smart City and will help in further planned AV shuttle deployments as first/last mile solutions having a broad impact on the mobility choices of the inhabitants of Columbus. Results of project UNIFY will be used by the City of Columbus in determining the feasibility of running AV shuttles in many planned routes through preliminary testing of technology using our unified approach AV shuttles throughout the city and evaluating possible solutions by different vendors using the rating and evaluation method developed. This is both the biggest impact and technology transfer of the results of project UNIFY. The vendors of automated driving shuttles operating in geo-fenced areas in smart cities are usually small start-up companies and benefit from the use of a unified, scalable and replicable software, hardware, control and decision making architecture. On the other hand, the smart cities where these shuttles operate benefit from a digital mockup type evaluation system and from the capability of testing the feasibility of AV shuttle operation in selected geo-fenced areas using easily configured AVs for preliminary testing and data collection. The outcomes of project UNIFY serve both of these purposes.

The project UNIFY had three parts. In the first part, a unified software, hardware, control and decision making architecture that uses a model based design approach within the Simulink development environment consisting of generic Simulink interfaces for typical sensors like GPS, camera, lidar, radar and V2V modem, generic Simulink steering, throttle and brake actuators, all within a generic multi-agent Simulink automated driving architecture connected by generic and scalable control and decision making blocks was developed. Available and widely used software like ROS, dSpace RT-Maps, Autoware and NVIDIA Driveworks were also integrated into this unified architecture. In the second part of the project, a scalable and replicable method of designing longitudinal and lateral vehicle dynamics controllers using the parameter space approach to parametric robust control was developed and later used successfully in scaling path tracking, collision avoidance maneuvering and car following from our Ford Fusion to our Dash EV autonomous vehicle platform. The third part developed an evaluation and rating system used to evaluate different automated driving control systems utilizing the unified and scalable architecture of the project. A digital mockup of autonomous shuttle driving in a geo-fenced area was created in our hardware-in-the-loop simulator. This mock-up environment which also included other cars, road infrastructure and pedestrians was used to evaluate decision making algorithms of AV shuttles. Perception sensor data was also collected in planned deployment sites to test AV shuttle perception algorithms.

The scalability and replicability of the unified architecture developed in this project were demonstrated using four different vehicles. Two of these vehicles were passenger sedans (2017 and  2015 Ford Fusion hybrid electric vehicles) and the other two were smaller neighborhood electric vehicles (Dash EVs by Innova). The hardware and software architecture was easily replicated in upgrading to the newer vehicles in the passenger vehicle class and in the neighborhood electric vehicle class. Scalability was demonstrated by easily scaling path tracking, collision avoidance maneuvering, car following and connected vehicle applications from the passenger vehicle class to the neighborhood electric vehicle class. This unified architecture and its scalability and replicability properties were disseminated in journal and conference papers, conference presentations and invited speeches and were also incorporated into a graduate and advanced undergraduate course on Autonomy in Vehicles which was also attended in distance education format by practicing engineers in two major automotive OEMs. Students taking the course designed autonomous shuttle applications for the Ohio State University AV shuttle pilot route and the City of Columbus’s planned Easton Town Center AV shuttle route as part of their homework projects. The simulation based evaluation methods of the project UNIFY were also used by the students during those two projects.
